docs.lead_paragraph: The Economix blog has two articles today illuminating the profit-and-loss innards of the insurance business. A Princeton economist, Uwe E. Reinhardt, notes that one advocacy group representing insurers in the small-group and individual market has indicated that its member companies lose money if they are forced to pay more than 65 percent of premiums back out to cover medical claims.
docs.abstract: On the Economix blog, two articles illuminating the innards of insurance.
docs.snippet: On the Economix blog, two articles illuminating the innards of insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: It wasn't pretty at times, but at 2:15 a.m. Friday, the Senate Finance Committee finished debating amendments to its sweeping health care legislation. The bill will now be delivered to the Congressional Budget Office for a crucial cost estimate. A final vote on the measure is expected next week.

headline.main: Debating Done, Now Comes a Budget Work-Up Before Voting on the Baucus Bill

docs.abstract: The Senate Finance Committee has finished debating amendments to its sweeping health care legislation. After a budget analysis, the bill is expected to be put to a final vote next week.
docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee has finished debating amendments to its sweeping health care legislation. After a budget analysis, the bill is expected to be put to a final vote next week.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department announced on Friday morning that the unemployment rate rose again, to 9.8 percent for September, the highest it's been during the economic downturn. While Obama administration advisers have said in recent months that they expect the rate could climb to 10 percent, this is the highest rate reached since 1983.
docs.abstract: The latest Labor Department report includes higher jobs loss figures than anticipated.
docs.snippet: The latest Labor Department report includes higher jobs loss figures than anticipated.

byline.original: By BERNIE BECKER and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: If you put together two of the fascinating nuggets from Nelson Schwartz's article on Swiss health care, you end up with a nice little lesson about health economics. He writes:
docs.abstract: The Swiss pay more out of pocket than we do for health care -- and less over all.
docs.snippet: The Swiss pay more out of pocket than we do for health care -- and less over all.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of eight leading climate economists has a message for United States senators now considering a bill to cap emissions: don't think of long-term mitigation costs as a massive expenditure, but rather a form of reasonably-priced "planetary climate insurance."
docs.abstract: A group of eight leading climate economists have a message for United States senators now considering a new bill to cap emissions: think of it as reasonably-priced "planetary climate insurance."
docs.snippet: A group of eight leading climate economists have a message for United States senators now considering a new bill to cap emissions: think of it as reasonably-priced "planetary climate insurance."

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: What Portion of Premiums Should Insurers Pay Out in Benefits?

docs.abstract: Health insurance industry groups have fought regulations to pay out at least 70 percent of the premiums they collect in the form of health benefits, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Health insurance industry groups have fought regulations to pay out at least 70 percent of the premiums they collect in the form of health benefits, an economist writes.

headline.main: New Twists in the Health Debate
headline.print_headline: New Twists in the Health Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Actuaries will pay $600,000 to Bruce Schobel, who was to have become its president.

headline.seo: Academy of Actuaries Settles Dispute With Bruce Schobel
headline.main: Academy of Actuaries Settles Dispute With Bruce Schobel
headline.print_headline: Actuary Group Settles a Legal Dispute

docs.snippet: The American Academy of Actuaries will pay $600,000 to Bruce Schobel, who was to have become its president.

docs.lead_paragraph: Seizing on a new line of attack, Republican leaders say the proposed health care overhaul is a vehicle for a barrage of hidden and not-so-hidden tax increases.

headline.main: Republicans Call Health Legislation a Tax Increase
headline.print_headline: Republicans Call Health Legislation a Tax Increase

docs.snippet: Seizing on a new line of attack, Republican leaders say the proposed health care overhaul is a vehicle for a barrage of hidden and not-so-hidden tax increases.

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: The move would help people facing financial burdens in buying even the cheapest insurance available.
